urn:contentItem:5W8B-GB31-JBHT-D4H2-00000-00Dow Volatile After Two Days of Steep Losses; American Pastor Releases; Michael Devastates Florida; U.S. and China Talking; Michael Death Toll now 13; Facebook Save Hackers Stole Information from 29 million Accounts; Tesla Gives Customers until Monday for $7500 Tax Credit2018-10-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:22ZLexisNexisDow Volatile After Two Days of Steep Losses; American Pastor Releases; Michael Devastates Florida; U.S. and China Talking; Michael Death Toll now 13; Facebook Save Hackers Stole Information from 29 million Accounts; Tesla Gives Customers until Monday for $7500 Tax CreditLanhamFULL TEXT

NEIL CAVUTO, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Trish, I look forward to next week, 8:00 p.m. So my last handoff to you, young lady, for now, right?

TRISH REGAN, "THE INTELLIGENCE REPORT" HOST: You're going to get me all like sentimental.

CAVUTO: O, I know. It's the way it is.

REGAN: Again, the market has to close up, right?

CAVUTO: It's got to.

REGAN: It's my last day here at 2:00 o'clock.

CAVUTO: It will. It will.

REGAN: All right. Thank you. Fingers crossed.

CAVUTO: All righty.

REGAN: All right. Thanks, Neil.

Breaking right now, everyone, another wild day on Wall Street, we're looking at a Dow that's up, right now, 95 points after being up 400 points at the open and then it dipped a little down into negative territory, now we're back up. Let's see what happened. It's a wild ride. We got a live report from the NYSE straight ahead.

I am Trish Regan. Welcome, everyone, to the final edition, dare I say, the final edition of "The Intelligence Report."

Also breaking today, an American pastor who has been detained in Turkey for the last two years is finally coming back home. President Trump thrilled with the news, tweeting in all caps, "Pastor Brunson just released, will be home soon!" We have a live report coming up from the White House straight ahead.

And take a look here at this devastating video coming to us from Mexico Beach, Florida. The small coastal town decimated by Hurricane Michael. We have a live report from Panama City, Florida on the cleanup and relief efforts.

But first, we're going to Deirdre Bolton who's on the floor of the NYSE for more on today's wild ride. What's causing it?

DEIRDRE BOLTON, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: It's right, Trish, especially following the previous two days that we've had. So the big question of course today is can these gains hold?

So right now I want to call your attention to the tech stocks. These had been the most beaten down in the past of two sessions combined. They are what is holding up the gains as we see right now.

So I'm going to go through some of the names that you know well. We have Apple, Amazon, Google and NVIDIA, I should say. Alphabet Google still down for the week but very much the strongest mover today. Of course we pay a lot of attention because as far as the weighting go in the S&P 500 we know that tech by market cap is the heaviest, the strongest as far as the industry groups go.

Trish, we're also focused on the financials, as you know four banks reported before the earnings started. They remain actually the biggest drag right now on the broader markets. So interestingly enough, JPMorgan shares (ph) beat on the top and the bottom line earlier. This was mover to the upside that has since changed.

And it seems as if traders are focused on one key part of the outlook statement. I'm going to read it directly. The non-interest revenue growth will be between seven percent and eight percent.

But the thing that is concerning a lot of investors in the stock, and perhaps even in the broader industry is market dependent. Meaning, let's see how our business does outside of the profitable business that we expect to have by loaning out money as rates go higher.

As for some of the other financials, PNC is down. It has actually had a very rough week. Wells Fargo and Citi, the other two companies that reported earnings before the bell, little bit of mixed. Basically one beating on revenue, slight miss on earnings, one beating on earnings, slight miss on revenue, both of those stocks heading marginally higher.

So, Trish, the push and pull is basically tech versus financials. Back to you.

REGAN: All right. Deirdre Bolton, thank you very much.

Joining me right now onset, our very own Kristina Partsinevelos. We also have Kingsview Asset Management Chief Investment Officer, Scott Martin. Good to see both of you both guys.

I believe -- do we have Paul Dietrich with us too? Another investor. He's joining -- there we go. There you -- I knew you're around there, Paul.

PAUL DIETRICH, FAIRFAX GLOBAL MARKET CEO: Hi, Trish.

REGAN: I'm going to start with you. Wild market, is this the way of the future right now or is this just a little blip?

DIETRICH: What this is, is, this is a reversion to mean normalizing correction. One of the things that's happened over this past, actually more than a year is that you've had five big tech stocks that have dominated the performance as of the end of August, they were represented 47 percent of the performance of the S&P 500. And what we've seen basically, really for the last month or so, is the tech stocks have been going down and they're reverting to mean of a more normalized stock market trend. And they're very, very high in P.E.s.

And so, I see this as a very healthy correction in that, you know, the tech stocks are coming back in line with the rest of the 495 stocks in the S&P 500.

REGAN: Kristina?

KRISTINA PARTSINEVELOS, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: I think we can't just solely focus on tech. If you look yesterday I was on the New York Stock Exchange 2:43 p.m., just the intraday volume dropped so much, that we haven't seen a drop like that in eight years since the "flash crash." So I think that based of the traders I was speaking to -- volatility is going to continue to be an issue.

We're heading -- earnings started today at JPMorgan. JPMorgan is supposed to be good right now. Their revenue climbed higher, up what, 24 percent for the quarter, the third quarter. Sorry, profits up 24 percent. And yet you're seeing that stock down today which you would expect it to be better like Deirdre brought up. The guidance is concerning.

So I think going into the earning season, looking into the future, we're going to be paying close attention to the guidance of a lot of these companies.

REGAN: Well, you know, right now, earning seem, actually Scott, pretty good, right? I mean, so far so good. We've got strong economic fundamentals. I do wonder if some people are saying to themselves, wait a second, you know what? I can make a little more money on the C.D. at the local bank because Treasury yields are going up, interest rates are going up. And so, is this a bit of a rotation as well and that people now have more opportunity in the investment landscape?

SCOTT MARTN, KINGSVIEW ASSET MANAGEMENT CIO: It could be. Now, gosh, I hope that mom and pop sitting at home aren't thinking about that, you know, two percent or 2.5 percent C.D. just yet, Trish, because I think --

REGAN: Well, Scott, you know that I'm using that to characterize something broader, right?

MARTIN: OK. Sure.

REGAN: Which is that investors are saying to themselves, "OK, I have more optionality. It used to be equities are the only game in town. Well maybe I can put a little money in fixed income now."

MARTIN: Fair play, right, exactly. Maybe the 10-year bond. And so you're right. That's providing an alternative. And I to the point that k-parts made was visibility is in question here.

I get it that earning are good, you know in fact, I think the bar, at least psychologically based on some of the preannouncements has been lowered, so that's good. But the visibility is cloudy. I mean, you look at the incident surrounding tariffs. GDP obviously going forward, it look strong, but then the job market is kind of maybe leveling off here, I mean, still growing but not growing at the higher rates that we saw it earlier this year.

REGAN: Yes, but is that enough to cause you to just say, you know, throw in the towel and go?

SCOTT: Well, what it could do though, here's the thing, in highly psychological market as Paul mentioned, you know, this is a market, Trish, that could take that as a reason to sell first and ask questions later. And that's the story of say, certainly yesterday and the day before.

REGAN: How does the Fed factor into all of this, Paul? By the way the President is not too happy with the Fed right now. Most presidents don't really like the Fed.

DIETRICH: Yes. Exactly. Yes, I mean, --

REGAN: Maybe Obama did. He should have anyway.

DIETRICH: -- let's face it. This is an election year and President Trump is really promoting the State of the U.S. economy which is really good and it's firing on all cylinders. And so when you see a stock market collection like we've seen over the last few days, you know he has to blame someone, and so he is blaming the Federal Reserve.

I think this is normal. This is politics. But --

SCOTT: Dangerous.

DIETRICH: No, no, no.

REGAN: No, by the way, no, it's not dangerous.

DIETRICH: Not if it's all rhetoric.

REGAN: It's only if the Fed actually listened but, Scott, I'm going to give Jay Powell a little more credit than that.

PARTSINEVELOS: Oh, Jay Powell actually come out in broadcast interview with NPR Marketplace that he's going to follow through with this. He said that he's going to stick to the facts, and what the economy is showing, not a political play. And it shouldn't be a political play.

REGAN: No, absolutely.

PARTSINEVELOS: You have presidents who have been very --

MARTIN: Reverse the lines.

PARTSINEVELOS: -- critical of monetary policy. But in this case look at where interest rates are now. Look at it historically, they've been very, very low. The economy is growing.

Yes, we had inflation coming at 2.3 percent, but we have a very, very tight labor force. You have Walgreen saying that they're going to increase their salaries, Amazon announcing that $15 per hour. So there's possibly this inflation fear right now.

REGAN: You know we were talking to the gentleman, the founder, Jerry Fine of Oak Tree Asset Management just the other day, and one thing that he mentioned was that a lot of the companies he speaks to regularly are starting to say, places like Walmart for example, you know, inflation is running a little higher than what you might think. That wages are growing faster than 2.8 percent. And their production costs are increasing.

And so the Fed needs to take all that into account. And that, Kristina, their job is to make sure that, you know, things don't get too overheated, right?

PARTSINEVELOS: Right.

REGAN: Because then you get problems down the road. But it's a tightrope, the Fed got to walk.

PARTSINEVELOS: Which is -- it's very difficult position for Jay Powell to be in. But I think also we should preface that there is two different kinds of inflation. You also have manmade inflation when you have the tariffs come into play.

So the fact that literally 50 percent of all Chinese goods that enter the United States at this moment are being taxed. And potentially could be all 100 percent. That inevitably will have an effect on companies, on us.

REGAN: Yes, no, I get you, I hear you. But Scott, I think that that's kind of a short-term play. How are you thinking about China right now? And you heard me say, if we don't start dealing with this, and the theft of intellectual property, $600 billion a year, if we don't deal with it now it's going to be a whole lot harder to deal with it in the future.

MARTIN: I agree. To your question, how is China? I don't know, look at their stock market, it's absolutely blasted.

REGAN: It's not good.

MARTIN: No, not good.

So, you're right, that probably brings them to the table, because honestly, Trish, before this tariff talk really heated up, I mean if you go back even to last year, there were problems under the surface in China, anyway economically. So now this is really starting to hurt them.

Your point with Kristina is good about inflation because if you look at material cost guides, those are dropping by enlarge around the world. You know it's not that hard to produce things anymore. There's a lot of price competitiveness other than oil that we've seen bump up recently.

So, to me the inflation story is all about wages and it's nowhere.

REGAN: All right, so Scott, are you buying right now or you're going to sit by the sidelines and wait?

MARTIN: Yes, sit by the fire, and maybe have a cigar and think about it. But I will be buying probably next week. I think you got to --

REGAN: All right.

MARTIN: -- let the psychological kind of walkout here, though.

REGAN: You should have bought yesterday. Paul, your thoughts, final thoughts.

MARTIN: Or maybe this morning. Right.

DIETRICH: The story that nobody is talking about with inflation, because inflation has been a problem in the past, but -- and we've only seen for the last 60 years bad inflation where the government spends too much and then has to print money that causes inflation. But there's good inflation. You know when wages are going up, and prices are going up because people can price in the cost, that creates a virtues circle and government doesn't have to print money.

MARTIN: It's natural.

REGAN: Right. And listen, you don't want to have to fight deflation, that's whole other can of worms that incredibly --

MARTIN: Can't win that fight.

REGAN: Yes. It's good to see you guys. Thank you, Kristina, Paul, Scott.

I do want to point out we've got breaking news coming in to us right now. The President says he will be traveling to Florida and to Georgia early next week to survey some of the damage that are caused by Hurricane Michael. This is the tweet that he just issued.

He said, "People have no idea how hard Hurricane Michael has hit the great state of Georgia. I will be visiting both Florida and Georgia early next week. We are working hard on every area and every state that was hit, we are with you."

Also breaking today, American Pastor Andrew Bronson is on his way home after being released by a Turkish court. So what does that mean for U.S. and Turkey relations going forward? I'm going to asking New York Congressman, Tom Reed, that very question next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

REGAN: Another roller coaster ride here but at least for now anyway, we're in positive territory. You can see we've been all over the place. Up as much as 400 in change as we started the day. And then down, well, now, still up, barely.

Meanwhile, we've got some good news out of Turkey today as the American Pastor Andrew Brunson is now on a plane home after a court ruled he should be released. He had been sentenced to more than three years on terrorism charges despite living in Turkey for more than 20 years.

President Trump had imposed sanctions, some pretty strict sanctions on Turkey in an attempt to secure his release. And he tweeted, "Pastor Brunson just released, will be home soon!" He is going to feel, I would imagine feel pretty good about that.

Edward Lawrence is live at the White House with the latest

And Edward, fill us in.

EDWARD LAWRENCE, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: Yes. I can tell you right now that Pastor Brunson, we understand, is on a plane on his way to Germany, to an air force base to get medical treatment there just to make sure that he is OK. Then White House sources are saying he's going to be on a plane to Andrews Air Force Base arriving tomorrow at 6:00 a.m. There might be some ceremony but he's obviously relieved. His family, they said they are just relieved about this news.

In fact his lawyer says he thanked everyone for their prayers.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JAY SEKULOW, AMERICAN CENTER FOR LAW AND JUSTICE: Many of you have been praying for this day. I want to thank you. I know the pastor and his entire family want to thank you as well. And of course, a huge thank you to the President and his team for securing the release of Andrew Brunson.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LAWRENCE: Now a Turkish court actually convicted Pastor Andrew Brunson on terrorism charges, gave him little more than three years, but then give him time served and they lifted the travel ban which is the reason he's able to now leave the country. He's gotten on a plane as we said. The White House saying that there was no deal made with Turkey to make this happen. So nothing was on the table.

Turkey may have been doing this to garner some goodwill. They are looking for help with the investigation on the missing columnist that went into the Saudi consulate in Turkey.

Now officials in Turkey believe that he was killed inside that consulate, Jammal Khashoggi. Now, they say that they have audio and video evidence that point to that effect. "The Wall Street Journal" reporting that that evidence has been shown to U.S. intelligence agencies.

Now, Saudi's officially said that he left even though video shows him going in but not coming out.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ADAM KINZINGER (R-IL), HOUSE FOREIGN RELATIONS COMMITTEE: If it's true, it appears that it is, that he was murdered in their consulate by an assassination team, there needs to be some significant consequences to that. I think that's maybe eventually targeted sanctions on individuals, that, you know, any other host of things available to this administration.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LAWRENCE: Now the President saying that even if the Saudi government is proven to be behind this disappearance, the U.S. may not cancel its arms deal that it has with Saudi Arabia which includes fighter jets. The President saying that does not want to see the jobs go to Russia.

Now on another note here, the senior White House official telling us that they are moving in the direction for a meeting between with the Chinese president, President Xi Jinping, and President Donald Trump next month at the G20 summit, a bilateral, one-on-one meeting between the two. China trying to avoid the 25 percent tariffs that will be bumped up at January 1st. They are worried about their market and the effects that will happen.

The Chinese president possibly trying to get the President to back off those tariffs. Now, the President would like China to step up and make some changes, at least move forward towards a trade deal with the U.S.

Trish?

REGAN: Thank you very much, Edward Lawrence.

All right. Joining me right now with reaction, we have Republican Congressman Tom Reed of New York. Good to have you here, sir.

Congressman, I'm going to start first on the China front. Do you think they might actually be willing to give a little here? I mean, we are their biggest customer.

TOM REED (R), NEW YORK CONGRESSMAN: I think they are --

REGAN: Not doing them any favors, right? This whole sort of "trade war" if you can call it that, it's not helping China?

REED: No. I would agree with that assessment. This is not sustainable for China. They need to come to the table. And I believe that is exactly where these talks will lead that they are recognizing. That it is not in their interests, nor in America's interest to continue a protracted trade war. It's time for us to come together. It's time for China to be held accountable for their unfair trade practices. And I think they are in a position to have to sit at the table to resolve this.

REGAN: You know, Congressman the difference, however is that in China they don't have to get elected. I mean you got to get elected every two years, right? And consequently if the economy starts to turn and if corporations starts getting kind of upset including some of, say your donor, sir, that they can't access the Chinese markets like they used to because of all of these problems, then at what point does it start to really bite into the ability of American politicians to really do what's best here where just to confront the problem?

REED: Well I think Trish, if you look at from the other perspective. You know, China has -- they're not subject to election, but I will tell you they have tremendous amount of internal strife. If their people don't have an expanding economy to go to work, they can't put food on table, they can't put a roof over their head. That causes a tremendous amount of the stability and instability in China.

And when you look at what China is doing in regards to a debt to GDP, it's not sustainable there either. So China cannot withstand these. And I understand the political pressure, but this elephant needs to be confronted. And that's what we're doing.

REGAN: Why, why is everybody --

REED: We're holding them accountable once and for all.

REGAN: --kind of ignore it. I mean for -- why is it that -- I mean we -- and I shouldn't say they ignore it. Actually I've talked to former Treasury Secretary Bob Rubin about this and he pointed out that China is indeed a big, big problem. And he tried to address it during the Clinton years. But everybody has tried, right?

Tim Geithner, I remember trying to take this one and spend time in China trying to deal with this. The theft of intellectual property is a real problem for us. And yet, no one was quite as vocal about it shall we say as this President. Is it because they feared to this talk of a trade war? Do they fear a backlash from American CEOs that would say, "No, no, we need to be over there, we want to be over there, it's a big market for us?"

REED: I think that pressure was there. But now obviously under this administration and with our President, we're seeing a disruptive policy put on the table. And China can't take the risk of not having America follow the status quo, the traditional path if you would. And so what I believe is happening is they're recognizing that President Trump is serious. And that he is serious about holding them accountable for these unfair trade practices. And now is the time you're seeing results in China's movement, in their policy shifts to come to the table to recognize they have to resolve these issues.

REGAN: Real quick, before I let you go. It's very good news that the Pastor has been released . Does this show you that sanctions can actually work, Congressman?

REED: Absolutely, and you can get results through strength. And that's what the administration sent to Turkey. Is what it said to Turkey is we are not going to allow an American citizen to be held captive. And now we should all celebrate as Americans, as Democrats and Republicans that Pastor Brunson is coming home and coming home to his family. That is a joint celebration every American should be proud of.

REGAN: Here, here, I agree. Thank you so much. Congressman Reed, good to see you.

REED: Thanks.

REGAN: All right, we're going to be following these markets again throughout the hour as we watch Dow that's up 52 points right now, 25,101 is the level. Stay with us.

Residents, meanwhile in the Florida Panhandle, they are coming to terms with the utter destruction that Hurricane Michael had left behind. We have a live report on cleanup and relief efforts coming up next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

REGAN: Very sad scene in Florida right now. In fact, everywhere you look in the Florida Panhandle, what you see is utter devastation. You have beach front homes have been completely obliterated. Only slabs of concrete remaining, entire communities actually destroyed when category 4 Hurricane Michael roared ashore this week. This destruction is being called catastrophic.

Billions of dollars will be needed to rebuild. And now 13 deaths are being blamed on the most powerful hurricane to hit the U.S. mainland in a generation.

And Michael is not done yet. Causing flash flooding, heavy rains as far away as Virginia. Connell McShane is joining me right now on the phone from one of the hardest hit areas, Panama City, Florida.

Hey, Connell.

CONNELL MCSHANE, FOX BUSINESS NEWS ANCHOR (via telephone): Hi there Trish.

We're just east of Panama City right now. We've been moving around a lot today as much as we can. And we've been encountering some of the same difficulties as the people here are in trying to recover from Hurricane Michael and as the first-responders are been trying to help those people so badly hurt by this hurricane.

Let me start in Mexico Beach where we spent part of our afternoon and evening yesterday before the curfew went into place. Well I'm sure you've seen what we'll be able to show now some of the video of Mexico Beach that we and our other Fox colleagues were able to shoot particularly some of the aerial shots where you can see just how Hurricane Michael caused so much destruction. And that's the word, not damage, it's destruction.

There were homes that were buried a day before the hurricane which just aren't there anymore. It's not as if they were damaged. They were completely wiped out. I was speaking to some of the National Guard troops who are assigned to Mexico Beach, one in particular told me he's from this area, has worked a number of hurricanes and never seen anything even close to this bad.

Now when you get back to the area you mentioned, Panama City where we were earlier in the day, there are parts of it in particular in Panama City Beach are starting to recover. Even some power that's starting to come back. But those few and far between as of this morning, 90 percent of that town in Bay County was still without power.

We move to the east where we are. Then you encounter the communication difficulties that are really making things doubly difficult for everybody trying to respond to this hurricane. And that's why I'm speaking to you now on this side of the road on a satellite phone because in an area where the cell phone service was perfect yesterday it no longer works at all today. So that's one of the things the companies no doubt are trying to get in here and get their towers back up and running. But it depends on which service provider you have. For example, many of us have AT&T and that was working in some areas beautifully.

Many of the people who live here do not have Verizon or Sprint or what have you and they weren't working at all. So, it depends where you are, what service provider you have. And people are having difficult even telling someone that they're having trouble.

And, you know, we're running to a lady earlier for example, we've been able to ride out the storm. She's OK. The tree that came down, a giant oak tree fell into the street, thank goodness, not into her house but she was having difficulty telling her family she was OK.

Finally, she was able to walk up of a block and randomly Facebook Messenger it came on her phone even though it didn't seem that she has service she leave (ph) to give a quick message t some of her family members. So that's the kind of thing that it making hard to recover from this hurricane. The idea that communicating is so difficult.

I will say Trish, the transportation has improved a little. It's all relative but some of the road there were completely closed yesterday are now starting to reopen. Thanks for the hard work of some of the professionals and also some of the volunteers, neighbors helping neighbors pack with their saws and chainsaws and whatever (ph) to be able to cutdown some of tress and open the roads up.

So FEMA and the other authorities can get in. But that's a long way to go, Trish. It really is something else.

REGAN: Wow, quite an aftermath. Connell, thank you very much.

All right. Roller coaster here on the market up 81 right now. We've been up as much as 400 then we were down. So, where we're headed right now? It's a Friday. So investors are going into the weekend and of course, you know, a lot of this is gone to center around what happened come midterm elections, right? Because economic policy is going to be influenced by whoever is in office. Our panel is going to debate all that next

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

REGAN: All right. We're watching what has become a very volatile market this week. A couple rough days we had but today is looking a little better.

We're up 50 -- nearly 50 points. We had been trading up as much as 414 though. So, so much for that, but at least we're out of negative territory. The big question is, what are these markets really mean for Republicans come the midterms?

Joining me right now, James Freeman of "The Wall Street Journal" and Former Advisor to Bill Clinton, Doug Schoen. Good to see you both.

DOUG SCHOEN, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good to see you.

JAMES FREEMAN, "THE WALL STREET JOURNAL": Good to be here, Trish, thanks.

REGAN: Doug, I'm going to start with you. I mean people been feeling pretty good about the economy. I'd tell you all the economic data points do some very, very strong fundamentals. But, you know, when people open up their 401k's and they see that maybe it wasn't as good as it was last month, what kind of effect does that have on psychology for voters?

SCHOEN: You know, Trish, at this point, not to duck the question, it's hard to tell. Because usually these things take a little bit longer to play out than what you're describing which is, you know, the beginning of November, they get their 401k's. They're down and so they get less inclined to vote Republican.

Usually takes three to six months for the impact of a brief downturn and it has been brief and has been swift to be felt. So, as we sit here today can't say really anything. The polling shows if anything the Republicans up in the last week or so, certainly in the Senate races.

REGAN: James, I personally, and I said this earlier in the show. I think is a blip. I mean, I think there are very, very good fundamentals right now.

I think, you know, the China thing yes, it's a little bit of a threat but we'll make it through all of that. And as long as we continue to see wage growth and job growth. We're heading in the right direction and economic growth. But you know, nonetheless, if you have a market that's trading lower, I don't necessarily think it will in November. But if it were to--

FREEMAN: Yes.

REGAN: -- how does that influence in your view Republican voters?

FREEMAN: Well, I think the economy is a win for Republicans barring some huge, sort of catastrophic event. As you said the fundamentals are very strong. We just really got another reminder that this morning with the bank earnings

These are companies that get a pretty good window into the U.S. consumer. People paying bills on time. They're obviously able to find jobs. Earnings are good for the companies, the economy is growing. So I think that's all good and that would suggest this is a blip.

The sort of conventional wisdom is maybe the economy is so good since there are almost no economic problems. People kind of take that for granted and maybe they decide on other things.

REGAN: And that's was so hard, right, in midterms?

FREEMAN: Yes.

REGAN: I mean, you have to motivate --

FREEMAN: Right.

REGAN: -- voters get out there. And if they're feeling kind a OK, then, Doug, you run the risk of complacency. I do think Kavanaugh changed that, however. If there was any complacency among the Republican base, watching what happened with Judge Kavanaugh may have them thinking differently?

SCHOEN: Well, certainly that's the initial indication but we've got you know, some 20 something days to go until the election. And, whether there are twists and turns in terms of enthusiasm and attitudes, really remains to be seen.

A bunch of the most recent midterms have swung in the last week to 10 days. So I think it's not clear what's going to happen but I think James is right. If you look at all the indicators and certainly, Trish, you as well, it's more -- much more good news economically for the Republicans, notwithstanding that midterms typically go for the out party, the opposition.

REGAN: Yes. So, is all this at risk, James? I mean, if the Republicans are not successful in midterms? Because you know, we've heard many Democrats say they like to reverse the tax cut and they like to tax the wealthy?

FREEMAN: Yes.

REGAN: And tax everyone else along the way, including corporations et cetera. So, is some of this policy really at risk?

FREEMAN: Well, I think you have to say this at risk because depending on how big -- let's just imagine a big Democratic wave, if president Trump then feels the need to negotiate to do deals, to strike the "art of the deal" with Nancy Pelosi and Chuck Schumer, that could be a very different policy mix. It's -- obviously if you look at most of his history Donald Trump was not a super conservative guy. Does he evolve back if he is dealing with Congressional leadership with big democratic majorities? So that would be a question.

REGAN: Hey, Doug, can I just ask?

SCHOEN: Yes.

REGAN: Looking ahead to 2020, do you think Mike Bloomberg is going to be in the ring?

SCHOEN: You know, I don't think he's made a final decision. Certainly made it clear the other day that he was going to do everything he could to stand up to policies that the Trump administration is pursued, that he disagrees with. He is spending obviously close to $100 million on the midterm elections. So whatever the mayor or the former mayor does, he will be a force to be reckoned with. That's for sure.

REGAN: And he's never registered as a Democrat.

FREEMAN: Well, you know, if he likes to have --

SCHOEN: He is now.

FREEMAN: -- pro-business Democrats again. This -- for this reason I kind of doubt whether he can go anywhere.

REGAN: Yes.

FREEMAN: But it would be nice to see a kind of a market-oriented voice back in that party.

REGAN: Yes. It would be the alternative which is the Alexandria Cortez and the Bernie Sanders camp.

FREEMAN: A 100 percent.

REGAN: We don't need the socialist there. Anyway, good, red-blooded American capitalism and that's what the nation was founded on. Doug, James, good to see you guys. Thank you so much.

SCHOEN: Thank you so much, Trish.

FREEMAN: Thanks.

REGAN: All right 29 million Facebook users have had their information stolen in the massive security breach that happened there last month. Facebook says the information included everything from names and contact information to more personal profile information like places that people checked into and the devices used to access Facebook.

Facebook said users can check if they were affected by the attack, visiting Facebook's Online Help Center.

Tesla is giving its customers until Monday to place car orders eligible for a $7500 federal tax credit. Under federal law, the full tax credit lasts until the car company reaches 200,000 sales in 2010 which it definitely did in July. You know, any vehicles ordered by Monday are expected to be delivered by the end of the year.

President Trump sparking outraged and an outcry after slamming the Fed for being too aggressive, t does he have a point? Is the Fed getting a little too happy about these rate hikes? Our panel is going to weigh in on all that, I'll see you here next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP (R), PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We have interest rates going up at a clip that's much faster than certainly a lot of people including myself would have anticipated. I think the Fed is out of control. I think what they're doing is wrong. I think the Fed is far too stringent and they're making a mistake.

They're so tight. I think the Fed has gone crazy.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

REGAN: Tell us how you really feel. That was President Trump blasting the Fed for being too aggressive on interests rate hike. President Trump's very forward and obvious frustration with the Fed, well not doing so well with some folks but the head of JPMorgan Chase, Mr. Jamie Dimon is defending the President saying, and I, "I have never seen a President who wanted interest rates to go up." I think he's right on that one. Who would?

Joining me right now, the host of "Making Money" on the Fox Business network, Charles Payne, soon to be host of "Making Money" at 2:00 p.m., more on that in just a minute. Also Moody's Chief Economist, John Lonski.

John, yes, I don't blame him. Who the heck wants the cost of money to go up?

JOHN LONSKI, MOODY'S CHIEF ECONOMIST: You've got to be more diplomatic about your criticism of the Fed. You can't go out there because, say that they're lunatics or whatever he was saying. Jerome Powell is not crazy.

REGAN: You know what though, I know a lot of people are saying that. But, you know, this is a President who has a different style entirely, right. You know, he says what he thinks. And I'm sure there are plenty of Presidents that thought the Fed was doing a lousy job and acting crazy, but maybe they just never said it quite so explicitly.

LONSKI: That's right. And, you know, the fed has to keep an eye on financial markets. We now have the, you know, the overall market has sold off sharply thus far in the month of October. It's clearly higher. We have certain segments, interest sensitive segments of the market. For instance, that index of housing, sectors stock prices this afternoon is down 25 percent for the year-to-date. That's versus the overall market up by two percent.

And moreover, motor vehicle industry stock prices. So they're median decline for the year-to-date is roughly 23 percent. That's not good. And I think that's telling the Fed that perhaps there is reason to proceed with greater caution, not only when they hike rates --

REGAN: I see where it run.

LONSKI: -- but when they talk about rate hikes.

REGAN: IE, John Lonski agrees with President Trump. You don't want to see the Fed, maybe they're not crazy --

LONSKI: But with Jerome Powell is very intelligent, very wise man.

REGAN: Wow.

LONSKI: And I'm pretty sure that they're doing the best job possible.

REGAN: I'm pretty sure that even though he's the President of the United States, Charles Payne, the head of the Federal Reserve needs to be independent. And I would expect him to be independent. So he may hear a little of the chatter and a little of the noise, but really it comes down to the data, shouldn't it?

CHARLES PAYNE, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: It should come down to the data and the Fed has said over and over that it does. And I got to tell you the official communiques that they put out like the so-called dot plot in the FOMC, you know, communique. They suggest a very level-headed Fed that's not going to wreck the economy, but it's the comments that are made in his speech because almost every single day someone at the Fed is giving a speech somewhere around the world.

And I tell you, starting to roll markets in. And you know, there shouldn't be any sacred cows out there politi -- specifically on a political side. And why should the Fed be completely independent in the sense that it's unanswerable to anyone? It's not federal. It doesn't matter. It's sort of scary for the average person out there.

REGAN: Yes.

PAYNE: John just talking about housing being under pressure, autos being under pressure, that we're talking about the average American house hold. If the Fed is worried about, you know, the larger institutions, you know.

And then as far as President Trump's criticism, we went from 2008, 2014 with zero rate hikes. And this one in 2015, Janet Yellen figures she made a mistake, and she waited until after the election and she raised rates again. So, I can see --

REGAN: So you feel that many feels like, hey, that's fair.

PAYNES: Right.

REGAN: What were you doing for President Obama? And, you know, maybe send a little of that my way.

But here's the difference, John Lonski, in this environment right now we have a President who does understand the economy and understands that, you know, you want to unleash those spirits, those economic spirits, what do you, you lower taxes, you lessen regulation. That has translated into growth. We didn't get that from the Obama administration. So the Fed was only game in town.

LONSKI: And the President understands commercial real estate very well. And he must be getting some information that things are beginning to soften in a once very strong sector because of higher short-term interest rates and long-term interest rates.

And let's not forget, this has to be brought up, but for the first time in memory, perhaps history, we have the Fed firming monetary policy on two fronts. Not only are they hiking Fed funds and pushing short-term rates directly higher but they're passive reduction regarding their holdings of U.S. Treasury bonds is also putting some upward pressure on long-term interest rates.

So again, the Fed's got --

REGAN: OK.

LONSKI: -- to proceed very carefully.

REGAN: But very cautiously.

LONSKI: Yes.

REGAN: I mean, this is the delicate dance, right, that they're always walking. I mean, in the meantime, there are some legitimate or growing concerns I should say, Charles Payne, about inflation.

PAYNE: Yes. There are, there are, although, you know, this week what we saw inflation in the PPI number, airline travel went through the roof. You know no wonder delta had a pretty good earnings report. But then we got the CPI report yesterday, it was relatively benign.

And so, there are signs of inflation that's the kind of classical inflation signals that you would think that the Fed would be, you know, yellow flags or red flags. Although, we know they want to be ahead of the curve. There's just --

REGAN: Improve it (ph). They need to forget being as -- they're usually behind anyway.

PAYNE: Yes. Yes.

LONSKI: Today we can have report on import price inflation. Less than one percent for consumer goods, less than one percent for all imports excluding petroleum imports.

REGAN: All right. Well, here's the one --

LONSKI: That's not a sign of inflation taking off.

REGAN: If there's not enough and there's not enough wage growth, you know, maybe --

LONSKI: What's the hurry? What's -- there's no sense of urgency for rate hikes, that's it.

REGAN: All right. You and President Trump.

LONSKI: But Jerome Powell --

REGAN: Its given Jay Powell appear to your mind.

LONSKI: -- level at no. Yes.

REGAN: All right. Good to -- hey, Charles, I'm really excited for you.

PAYNE: Thank you.

REGAN: This is a great audience, you know --

PAYNE: Thank you.

REGAN: -- here at 2:00 p.m. And you're all going to see Charles beginning Monday, that's this Monday, 2:00 p.m. October 15th, "Making Money with Charles Payne," moves to 2:00, and well, I'm moving somewhere else. I'll tell you all about that next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

REGAN: All right. It's my last day on "The Intelligence Report". So this market better close up, right? We're up at 128 points. Let's hope it holds throughout the hour.

Big news? I shared this a little while ago with you. I'll tell you again all about it. I'm going to primetime, 8:00 p.m., starting Monday right after my good friend Lou, Lou Dobbs is on from 7:00 to 8:00. I will be on from 8:00 to 9:00. Kennedy will follow at 9:00. We are live at night right here on Fox Business.

I'm really excited about it. I, you know, I do want to point out just what an incredible three years it has been on this show. I mean, we created this show with you, really. With you. You tuned in and it's thanks to you that we're able to cream the competition for the last three years, something I'm really extremely proud of.

And it's thanks to you and it's thanks to this news cycle that, you know, we're expanding. We're expanding so we will be live, I will be live at 8:00 p.m. every night. The news keeps happening. It's a 24/7 news cycle.

We're on the front lines of history and I'm there with you, reporting on all of it. We analyze, we present both sides, you make the decisions about what is best for you, your family, and your wallet, right?

I want to thank -- I have an amazing team. I want to thank everybody on this team. So many of you in the control room right now have been with me from the very beginning, from the first day I was ever in this chair on this little set that we created, and it's been wonderful.

I've gotten to know all of you and your families and you've certainly gotten to know mine, including all three of the kids which love to come by and hang out at work and in the studio. So I'm going to miss all of you. Some of you are coming with me, of course, and I'm so excited for this new chapter and what we can do and what we can accomplish.

We have so many tremendous journalists here at Fox Business and we are in a tremendous news cycle. So this is the value add that we bring.

It's going to be a little different at home, so my husband and I had to get a little creative on this front because we used to have family dinner at 6:00 p.m. every night. Now it's going to be family breakfast at 6:30, when I take the kids to school.

And then it's following the news cycle for you. I'm looking forward to it. I'm going to see you Monday night.

Gosh, I hope this market ends up, Liz Claman, 137 points. We got to hang on to this one.

LIZ CLAMAN, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Yes. Yes. Let's give you a green good- bye. Trish, another live --

REGAN: Thank you.

CLAMAN: -- presence in primetime on Fox Business.

REGAN: Charles is going to be --

CLAMAN: Go. Go. Go.

REGAN: -- right here at 2:00 p.m.

CLAMAN: Yes. And we will welcome Charles and we wish you the best of luck, Trish.

REGAN: Thank you Liz.

END

urn:contentItem:5TGB-VHG1-DXH2-6166-00000-00Dow Volatile After Two Days of Steep Losses; American Pastor Releases; Michael Devastates Florida; U.S. and China Talking; Michael Death Toll now 13; Facebook Save Hackers Stole Information from 29 million Accounts; Tesla Gives Customers until Monday for $7500 Tax Credit2018-10-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:41:22ZLexisNexisINTELLIGENCE REPORT2:00 PM ESTPaul Dietrich, Tom Reed, Dough Schoen, James Freeman, John LonskiNEWSFinancial101201cb.232Dow Volatile After Two Days of Steep Losses; American Pastor Releases; Michael Devastates Florida; U.S. and China Talking; Michael Death Toll now 13; Facebook Save Hackers Stole Information from 29 million Accounts; Tesla Gives Customers until Monday for $7500 Tax CreditTrish Regan, Deirdre Bolton, Kristina Partsinevelos, Scott Martin, Edward Lawrence, Connell McShane, Charles Payne

NEIL CAVUTO, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Trish, I look forward to next week, 8:00 p.m. So my last handoff to you, young lady, for now, right?

TRISH REGAN, "THE INTELLIGENCE REPORT" HOST: You're going to get me all like sentimental.

CAVUTO: O, I know. It's the way it is.

REGAN: Again, the market has to close up, right?

CAVUTO: It's got to.

REGAN: It's my last day here at 2:00 o'clock.

CAVUTO: It will. It will.

REGAN: All right. Thank you. Fingers crossed.

CAVUTO: All righty.

REGAN: All right. Thanks, Neil.

Breaking right now, everyone, another wild day on Wall Street, we're looking at a Dow that's up, right now, 95 points after being up 400 points at the open and then it dipped a little down into negative territory, now we're back up. Let's see what happened. It's a wild ride. We got a live report from the NYSE straight ahead.

I am Trish Regan. Welcome, everyone, to the final edition, dare I say, the final edition of "The Intelligence Report."

Also breaking today, an American pastor who has been detained in Turkey for the last two years is finally coming back home. President Trump thrilled with the news, tweeting in all caps, "Pastor Brunson just released, will be home soon!" We have a live report coming up from the White House straight ahead.

And take a look here at this devastating video coming to us from Mexico Beach, Florida. The small coastal town decimated by Hurricane Michael. We have a live report from Panama City, Florida on the cleanup and relief efforts.

But first, we're going to Deirdre Bolton who's on the floor of the NYSE for more on today's wild ride. What's causing it?

DEIRDRE BOLTON, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: It's right, Trish, especially following the previous two days that we've had. So the big question of course today is can these gains hold?

So right now I want to call your attention to the tech stocks. These had been the most beaten down in the past of two sessions combined. They are what is holding up the gains as we see right now.

JOHN LONSKI, MOODY'S CHIEF ECONOMIST: You've got to be more diplomatic about your criticism of the Fed. You can't go out there because, say that they're lunatics or whatever he was saying. Jerome Powell is not crazy.

REGAN: You know what though, I know a lot of people are saying that. But, you know, this is a President who has a different style entirely, right. You know, he says what he thinks. And I'm sure there are plenty of Presidents that thought the Fed was doing a lousy job and acting crazy, but maybe they just never said it quite so explicitly.

LONSKI: That's right. And, you know, the fed has to keep an eye on financial markets. We now have the, you know, the overall market has sold off sharply thus far in the month of October. It's clearly higher. We have certain segments, interest sensitive segments of the market. For instance, that index of housing, sectors stock prices this afternoon is down 25 percent for the year-to-date. That's versus the overall market up by two percent.

And moreover, motor vehicle industry stock prices. So they're median decline for the year-to-date is roughly 23 percent. That's not good. And I think that's telling the Fed that perhaps there is reason to proceed with greater caution, not only when they hike rates --

REGAN: I see where it run.

LONSKI: -- but when they talk about rate hikes.

REGAN: IE, John Lonski agrees with President Trump. You don't want to see the Fed, maybe they're not crazy --

LONSKI: But with Jerome Powell is very intelligent, very wise man.

REGAN: Wow.

LONSKI: And I'm pretty sure that they're doing the best job possible.

REGAN: I'm pretty sure that even though he's the President of the United States, Charles Payne, the head of the Federal Reserve needs to be independent. And I would expect him to be independent. So he may hear a little of the chatter and a little of the noise, but really it comes down to the data, shouldn't it?

CHARLES PAYNE, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: It should come down to the data and the Fed has said over and over that it does. And I got to tell you the official communiques that they put out like the so-called dot plot in the FOMC, you know, communique. They suggest a very level-headed Fed that's not going to wreck the economy, but it's the comments that are made in his speech because almost every single day someone at the Fed is giving a speech somewhere around the world.

And I tell you, starting to roll markets in. And you know, there shouldn't be any sacred cows out there politi -- specifically on a political side. And why should the Fed be completely independent in the sense that it's unanswerable to anyone? It's not federal. It doesn't matter. It's sort of scary for the average person out there.

REGAN: Yes.

PAYNE: John just talking about housing being under pressure, autos being under pressure, that we're talking about the average American house hold. If the Fed is worried about, you know, the larger institutions, you know.

And then as far as President Trump's criticism, we went from 2008, 2014 with zero rate hikes. And this one in 2015, Janet Yellen figures she made a mistake, and she waited until after the election and she raised rates again. So, I can see --

REGAN: So you feel that many feels like, hey, that's fair.

PAYNES: Right.

REGAN: What were you doing for President Obama? And, you know, maybe send a little of that my way.

But here's the difference, John Lonski, in this environment right now we have a President who does understand the economy and understands that, you know, you want to unleash those spirits, those economic spirits, what do you, you lower taxes, you lessen regulation. That has translated into growth. We didn't get that from the Obama administration. So the Fed was only game in town.

LONSKI: And the President understands commercial real estate very well. And he must be getting some information that things are beginning to soften in a once very strong sector because of higher short-term interest rates and long-term interest rates.

And let's not forget, this has to be brought up, but for the first time in memory, perhaps history, we have the Fed firming monetary policy on two fronts. Not only are they hiking Fed funds and pushing short-term rates directly higher but they're passive reduction regarding their holdings of U.S. Treasury bonds is also putting some upward pressure on long-term interest rates.

So again, the Fed's got --

REGAN: OK.

LONSKI: -- to proceed very carefully.

REGAN: But very cautiously.

LONSKI: Yes.

REGAN: I mean, this is the delicate dance, right, that they're always walking. I mean, in the meantime, there are some legitimate or growing concerns I should say, Charles Payne, about inflation.

PAYNE: Yes. There are, there are, although, you know, this week what we saw inflation in the PPI number, airline travel went through the roof. You know no wonder delta had a pretty good earnings report. But then we got the CPI report yesterday, it was relatively benign.

And so, there are signs of inflation that's the kind of classical inflation signals that you would think that the Fed would be, you know, yellow flags or red flags. Although, we know they want to be ahead of the curve. There's just --

REGAN: Improve it (ph). They need to forget being as -- they're usually behind anyway.

PAYNE: Yes. Yes.

LONSKI: Today we can have report on import price inflation. Less than one percent for consumer goods, less than one percent for all imports excluding petroleum imports.

REGAN: All right. Well, here's the one --

LONSKI: That's not a sign of inflation taking off.

REGAN: If there's not enough and there's not enough wage growth, you know, maybe --

LONSKI: What's the hurry? What's -- there's no sense of urgency for rate hikes, that's it.

REGAN: All right. You and President Trump.

LONSKI: But Jerome Powell --

REGAN: Its given Jay Powell appear to your mind.

LONSKI: -- level at no. Yes.

REGAN: All right. Good to -- hey, Charles, I'm really excited for you.

PAYNE: Thank you.

REGAN: This is a great audience, you know --

PAYNE: Thank you.

REGAN: -- here at 2:00 p.m. And you're all going to see Charles beginning Monday, that's this Monday, 2:00 p.m. October 15th, "Making Money with Charles Payne," moves to 2:00, and well, I'm moving somewhere else. I'll tell you all about that next.

REGAN: All right. It's my last day on "The Intelligence Report". So this market better close up, right? We're up at 128 points. Let's hope it holds throughout the hour.

Big news? I shared this a little while ago with you. I'll tell you again all about it. I'm going to primetime, 8:00 p.m., starting Monday right after my good friend Lou, Lou Dobbs is on from 7:00 to 8:00. I will be on from 8:00 to 9:00. Kennedy will follow at 9:00. We are live at night right here on Fox Business.

I'm really excited about it. I, you know, I do want to point out just what an incredible three years it has been on this show. I mean, we created this show with you, really. With you. You tuned in and it's thanks to you that we're able to cream the competition for the last three years, something I'm really extremely proud of.

And it's thanks to you and it's thanks to this news cycle that, you know, we're expanding. We're expanding so we will be live, I will be live at 8:00 p.m. every night. The news keeps happening. It's a 24/7 news cycle.

We're on the front lines of history and I'm there with you, reporting on all of it. We analyze, we present both sides, you make the decisions about what is best for you, your family, and your wallet, right?

I want to thank -- I have an amazing team. I want to thank everybody on this team. So many of you in the control room right now have been with me from the very beginning, from the first day I was ever in this chair on this little set that we created, and it's been wonderful.

I've gotten to know all of you and your families and you've certainly gotten to know mine, including all three of the kids which love to come by and hang out at work and in the studio. So I'm going to miss all of you. Some of you are coming with me, of course, and I'm so excited for this new chapter and what we can do and what we can accomplish.

We have so many tremendous journalists here at Fox Business and we are in a tremendous news cycle. So this is the value add that we bring.

It's going to be a little different at home, so my husband and I had to get a little creative on this front because we used to have family dinner at 6:00 p.m. every night. Now it's going to be family breakfast at 6:30, when I take the kids to school.

And then it's following the news cycle for you. I'm looking forward to it. I'm going to see you Monday night.

Gosh, I hope this market ends up, Liz Claman, 137 points. We got to hang on to this one.

LIZ CLAMAN, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Yes. Yes. Let's give you a green good- bye. Trish, another live --

REGAN: Thank you.

CLAMAN: -- presence in primetime on Fox Business.

REGAN: Charles is going to be --

CLAMAN: Go. Go. Go.

REGAN: -- right here at 2:00 p.m.

CLAMAN: Yes. And we will welcome Charles and we wish you the best of luck, Trish.

REGAN: Thank you Liz.

NEIL CAVUTO, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: Trish, I look forward to next week, 8:00 p.m. So my last handoff to you, young lady, for now, right?

TRISH REGAN, "THE INTELLIGENCE REPORT" HOST: You're going to get me all like sentimental.

CAVUTO: O, I know. It's the way it is.

REGAN: Again, the market has to close up, right?

CAVUTO: It's got to.

REGAN: It's my last day here at 2:00 o'clock.

CAVUTO: It will. It will.

REGAN: All right. Thank you. Fingers crossed.

CAVUTO: All righty.

REGAN: All right. Thanks, Neil.

Breaking right now, everyone, another wild day on Wall Street, we're looking at a Dow that's up, right now, 95 points after being up 400 points at the open and then it dipped a little down into negative territory, now we're back up. Let's see what happened. It's a wild ride. We got a live report from the NYSE straight ahead.

I am Trish Regan. Welcome, everyone, to the final edition, dare I say, the final edition of "The Intelligence Report."

Also breaking today, an American pastor who has been detained in Turkey for the last two years is finally coming back home. President Trump thrilled with the news, tweeting in all caps, "Pastor Brunson just released, will be home soon!" We have a live report coming up from the White House straight ahead.

And take a look here at this devastating video coming to us from Mexico Beach, Florida. The small coastal town decimated by Hurricane Michael. We have a live report from Panama City, Florida on the cleanup and relief efforts.

But first, we're going to Deirdre Bolton who's on the floor of the NYSE for more on today's wild ride. What's causing it?

DEIRDRE BOLTON, FOX BUSINESS ANCHOR: It's right, Trish, especially following the previous two days that we've had. So the big question of course today is can these gains hold?

So right now I want to call your attention to the tech stocks. These had been the most beaten down in the past of two sessions combined. They are what is holding up the gains as we see right now.

So I'm going to go through some of the names that you know well. We have Apple, Amazon, Google and NVIDIA, I should say. Alphabet Google still down for the week but very much the strongest mover today. Of course we pay a lot of attention because as far as the weighting go in the S&P 500 we know that tech by market cap is the heaviest, the strongest as far as the industry groups go.

Trish, we're also focused on the financials, as you know four banks reported before the earnings started. They remain actually the biggest drag right now on the broader markets. So interestingly enough, JPMorgan shares (ph) beat on the top and the bottom line earlier. This was mover to the upside that has since changed.

And it seems as if traders are focused on one key part of the outlook statement. I'm going to read it directly. The non-interest revenue growth will be between seven percent and eight percent.

But the thing that is concerning a lot of investors in the stock, and perhaps even in the broader industry is market dependent. Meaning, let's see how our business does outside of the profitable business that we expect to have by loaning out money as rates go higher.

As for some of the other financials, PNC is down. It has actually had a very rough week. Wells Fargo and Citi, the other two companies that reported earnings before the bell, little bit of mixed. Basically one beating on revenue, slight miss on earnings, one beating on earnings, slight miss on revenue, both of those stocks heading marginally higher.

So, Trish, the push and pull is basically tech versus financials. Back to you.

REGAN: All right. Deirdre Bolton, thank you very much.

Joining me right now onset, our very own Kristina Partsinevelos. We also have Kingsview Asset Management Chief Investment Officer, Scott Martin. Good to see both of you both guys.

I believe -- do we have Paul Dietrich with us too? Another investor. He's joining -- there we go. There you -- I knew you're around there, Paul.

PAUL DIETRICH, FAIRFAX GLOBAL MARKET CEO: Hi, Trish.

REGAN: I'm going to start with you. Wild market, is this the way of the future right now or is this just a little blip?

DIETRICH: What this is, is, this is a reversion to mean normalizing correction. One of the things that's happened over this past, actually more than a year is that you've had five big tech stocks that have dominated the performance as of the end of August, they were represented 47 percent of the performance of the S&P 500. And what we've seen basically, really for the last month or so, is the tech stocks have been going down and they're reverting to mean of a more normalized stock market trend. And they're very, very high in P.E.s.

And so, I see this as a very healthy correction in that, you know, the tech stocks are coming back in line with the rest of the 495 stocks in the S&P 500.

REGAN: Kristina?

KRISTINA PARTSINEVELOS, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: I think we can't just solely focus on tech. If you look yesterday I was on the New York Stock Exchange 2:43 p.m., just the intraday volume dropped so much, that we haven't seen a drop like that in eight years since the "flash crash." So I think that based of the traders I was speaking to -- volatility is going to continue to be an issue.

We're heading -- earnings started today at JPMorgan. JPMorgan is supposed to be good right now. Their revenue climbed higher, up what, 24 percent for the quarter, the third quarter. Sorry, profits up 24 percent. And yet you're seeing that stock down today which you would expect it to be better like Deirdre brought up. The guidance is concerning.

So I think going into the earning season, looking into the future, we're going to be paying close attention to the guidance of a lot of these companies.

REGAN: Well, you know, right now, earning seem, actually Scott, pretty good, right? I mean, so far so good. We've got strong economic fundamentals. I do wonder if some people are saying to themselves, wait a second, you know what? I can make a little more money on the C.D. at the local bank because Treasury yields are going up, interest rates are going up. And so, is this a bit of a rotation as well and that people now have more opportunity in the investment landscape?

SCOTT MARTN, KINGSVIEW ASSET MANAGEMENT CIO: It could be. Now, gosh, I hope that mom and pop sitting at home aren't thinking about that, you know, two percent or 2.5 percent C.D. just yet, Trish, because I think --

REGAN: Well, Scott, you know that I'm using that to characterize something broader, right?

MARTIN: OK. Sure.

REGAN: Which is that investors are saying to themselves, "OK, I have more optionality. It used to be equities are the only game in town. Well maybe I can put a little money in fixed income now."

MARTIN: Fair play, right, exactly. Maybe the 10-year bond. And so you're right. That's providing an alternative. And I to the point that k-parts made was visibility is in question here.

I get it that earning are good, you know in fact, I think the bar, at least psychologically based on some of the preannouncements has been lowered, so that's good. But the visibility is cloudy. I mean, you look at the incident surrounding tariffs. GDP obviously going forward, it look strong, but then the job market is kind of maybe leveling off here, I mean, still growing but not growing at the higher rates that we saw it earlier this year.

REGAN: Yes, but is that enough to cause you to just say, you know, throw in the towel and go?

SCOTT: Well, what it could do though, here's the thing, in highly psychological market as Paul mentioned, you know, this is a market, Trish, that could take that as a reason to sell first and ask questions later. And that's the story of say, certainly yesterday and the day before.

REGAN: How does the Fed factor into all of this, Paul? By the way the President is not too happy with the Fed right now. Most presidents don't really like the Fed.

DIETRICH: Yes. Exactly. Yes, I mean, --

REGAN: Maybe Obama did. He should have anyway.

DIETRICH: -- let's face it. This is an election year and President Trump is really promoting the State of the U.S. economy which is really good and it's firing on all cylinders. And so when you see a stock market collection like we've seen over the last few days, you know he has to blame someone, and so he is blaming the Federal Reserve.

I think this is normal. This is politics. But --

SCOTT: Dangerous.

DIETRICH: No, no, no.

REGAN: No, by the way, no, it's not dangerous.

DIETRICH: Not if it's all rhetoric.

REGAN: It's only if the Fed actually listened but, Scott, I'm going to give Jay Powell a little more credit than that.

PARTSINEVELOS: Oh, Jay Powell actually come out in broadcast interview with NPR Marketplace that he's going to follow through with this. He said that he's going to stick to the facts, and what the economy is showing, not a political play. And it shouldn't be a political play.

REGAN: No, absolutely.

PARTSINEVELOS: You have presidents who have been very --

MARTIN: Reverse the lines.

PARTSINEVELOS: -- critical of monetary policy. But in this case look at where interest rates are now. Look at it historically, they've been very, very low. The economy is growing.

Yes, we had inflation coming at 2.3 percent, but we have a very, very tight labor force. You have Walgreen saying that they're going to increase their salaries, Amazon announcing that $15 per hour. So there's possibly this inflation fear right now.

REGAN: You know we were talking to the gentleman, the founder, Jerry Fine of Oak Tree Asset Management just the other day, and one thing that he mentioned was that a lot of the companies he speaks to regularly are starting to say, places like Walmart for example, you know, inflation is running a little higher than what you might think. That wages are growing faster than 2.8 percent. And their production costs are increasing.

And so the Fed needs to take all that into account. And that, Kristina, their job is to make sure that, you know, things don't get too overheated, right?

PARTSINEVELOS: Right.

REGAN: Because then you get problems down the road. But it's a tightrope, the Fed got to walk.

PARTSINEVELOS: Which is -- it's very difficult position for Jay Powell to be in. But I think also we should preface that there is two different kinds of inflation. You also have manmade inflation when you have the tariffs come into play.

So the fact that literally 50 percent of all Chinese goods that enter the United States at this moment are being taxed. And potentially could be all 100 percent. That inevitably will have an effect on companies, on us.

REGAN: Yes, no, I get you, I hear you. But Scott, I think that that's kind of a short-term play. How are you thinking about China right now? And you heard me say, if we don't start dealing with this, and the theft of intellectual property, $600 billion a year, if we don't deal with it now it's going to be a whole lot harder to deal with it in the future.

MARTIN: I agree. To your question, how is China? I don't know, look at their stock market, it's absolutely blasted.

REGAN: It's not good.

MARTIN: No, not good.

So, you're right, that probably brings them to the table, because honestly, Trish, before this tariff talk really heated up, I mean if you go back even to last year, there were problems under the surface in China, anyway economically. So now this is really starting to hurt them.

Your point with Kristina is good about inflation because if you look at material cost guides, those are dropping by enlarge around the world. You know it's not that hard to produce things anymore. There's a lot of price competitiveness other than oil that we've seen bump up recently.

So, to me the inflation story is all about wages and it's nowhere.

REGAN: All right, so Scott, are you buying right now or you're going to sit by the sidelines and wait?

MARTIN: Yes, sit by the fire, and maybe have a cigar and think about it. But I will be buying probably next week. I think you got to --

REGAN: All right.

MARTIN: -- let the psychological kind of walkout here, though.
